Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A major news network has just called for an immediate on-air comment to counter misinformation in a breaking story.
Story: I was folding the last of the towels when my phone buzzed, the screen lighting up with the name of the news producer I’d been hoping to hear from for weeks. My heart leapt—this was the chance to set the record straight, to speak for our cause on a national stage. But as I glanced around the living room, I saw the overflowing laundry basket and remembered the promise I’d made to my partner: clean clothes for the kids’ field trip tomorrow, and for his big meeting. He’d already picked up extra chores this week so I could attend late-night organizing sessions. I could hear the washing machine’s impatient beep, demanding attention. My mind raced, torn between the urgent call to action and the quiet, steady needs of home. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each expecting me to show up, to not let anyone down. The phone kept ringing, and I stood frozen, caught between the voice of my family and the voice of the movement, knowing I couldn’t answer both at once.
